results.title: Tennis elbow
results.creator_credit: John Thomson and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A tennis match provides the basis for a series of hilarious visual gags. A combination of absurd humour and satire is perpetrated by those graduates of the fringe comedy circuit, Kelso and Curtis and Los Trios Ringbarkus. Erwin Rado Award for Best Australian Short Fiction, Melbourne Film Festival 1983.

results.title: Tennis basics: the volley
results.brief_description: Dennis Ralston introduces the film by demonstrating the basic volley stroke, then using animation techniques, the exact positions of each part of the body at every stage in the swing is shown.

results.title: Tennis basics: the serve
results.brief_description: The serve is demonstrated by Dennis Ralston, and then the exact positions of each part of the body at every stage in the swing is shown. The precise movements are then repeated entirely in slow motion with frequent use of “freeze frames” for clear visualisation.
results.description: The serve is demonstrated by Dennis Ralston, and then the exact positions of each part of the body at every stage in the swing is shown. The precise movements are then repeated entirely in slow motion with frequent use of “freeze frames” for clear visualisation.

results.title: Tennis basics: the forehand
results.brief_description: Dennis Ralston introduces the film by demonstrating the basic forehand stroke and encouraging students to feel the movements as they are pictured. Animation shows the exact positions of each part of the body at every stage of the swing.

results.title: Tennis basics: the backhand
results.brief_description: American tennis professional Dennis Ralston demonstrates the backhand stroke. Simple animated figures are used to show the basic positions of the arms, legs, body and head during each phase of the swing. Viewer participation is also included.
results.description: American tennis professional Dennis Ralston demonstrates the backhand stroke. Simple animated figures are used to show the basic positions of the arms, legs, body and head during each phase of the swing. Viewer participation is also included.

results.title: Tennessee Williams: theater in process
results.creator_credit: Richard Slote, Suzanne Tedesko, Signet Productions and Encyclopaedia Britannica Educational Corporation
results.brief_description: A behind-the-scenes look at the production of the play “The red devil battery sign” by Tennessee Williams. Tennessee Williams talks about his career and about writing a play and how he works with a director rather than with the actors. The film shows a press conference, rehearsals of lines and then full rehearsals during which the director conveys his interpretation of some of the important symbols and speeches in the play
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Slote, Suzanne Tedesko, Signet Productions and Encyclopaedia Britannica Educational Corporation

results.title: Tennessee volunteers
results.brief_description: A project was sponsored by the University of Tennessee to build a children’s playground with the help of the community. In this way, building costs were low, and children involved gained more respect for the equipment, having helped to build it. Members of the community brought their own tools and gave their time, whilst local businesses donated equipment and the use of machinery.

results.title: Tennant Creek in passing
results.creator_credit: James Coffey, Frank Bagnall and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This film views Tennant Creek in the form of a passing glimpse, beginning with some long-shot filming of the natural environment and mines at sunrise in an approach to the town, focusing on buildings, inhabitants, passing vehicles and travellers, and completing the view with aerial shots moving away from Tennant Creek at sunset.
